Hi Colin!

I found your post on this group atypical but very interesting, s=
o I'm
would like to comment on some of the issues you've raised.
I must war=
n against reading too much into half-informed speculation on
the brain, and=
 some popular scientific magazines and especially blogs
are full of it.  Un=
fortunately, this is also true for some general
audience books written by s=
cientists. In science, facts must be well
separated from fiction and wild s=
peculation. In popular books, it is the
other way around. Both hold importa=
nt places, but the distinction must
be explicitly specified so that people =
can read both genres accordingly,
and give them credit for precision (scien=
tific publications) and
creativity (in mainstream books), not the other way=
 around.
From the academic perspective, the number of papers in neuroscienc=
e
today is huge, about 55.000 publications in 2008, and growing rapidly,
so=
 mining for details and consensus on sensitive issues is also a hard
job.
W=
ith that being said, I'll just make a few comments, trying to add
informati=
on which originates in neuroscience textbooks, courses and
papers.

Last su=
mmer I read Jeff Hawkins' book On Intelligence. One of the take
away points=
 for me was that the connectivity in real brains has a lot
of regular struc=
ture and order, but also some rather more messy
connectivity. I'm going fro=
m memory here but the pictue he paints is
one of cortical columns packed to=
gether vertically, columns have
layers (6 or so if memory serves) and intra=
-column connectivity
appears to be fairly well understood at a *very* broad=
 level, that is,
layer 1 neurons tend to connect to layers 2 & 3, etc.

At =
the top of the columns we then see connections reaching out over
the tops o=
f multiple columns, connecting up different regions
sometimes over very lon=
g distances - perhaps up to several
centimeters. It's interesting to contem=
plate what processes are
causing connections to form over such long ranges.=
 One explanation I
quite like is that the early brain (e.g. a newborn baby)=
 has a mass of
connections that have *not* yet been guided by any learning =
process -
so what is all this mass of connections doing? what arrangement o=
f
connectivity does it have and why? I suspect that our DNA describes
conne=
ctivity patterns in the newborn that are primed for learning and
that as le=
arning progresses some of these pre-existing connections are
strengthened (=
and grow new connections locally), and some wither away.
I'm speculating th=
at this early connectivity pattern includes some
proportion of long connect=
ions acting between distant regions. I
further speculate that this might be=
 partly responsible for the
various axon bundles that occur in the brain th=
at broadly follow the
same path in all (most?) people (e.g. from the retina=
 to the visual
cortex) - do 'primer' fibers grow by following a DNA bluepri=
nt during
the early stages of brain development?

Nothing in random in the =
connectivity of an infant's brain. The
precision of the connectivity is abs=
olutely astounding. We are born with
many times more connection and during =
puberty we loose most of them,
remaining with "just" the popularized figure=
 (about 100 trillion
connections). These connections or synapses  are genet=
ically mediated,
and do not only specify which parts of the brain connect t=
o which, but
also which parts of the target neuron's dendrites should a spe=
cific
fiber connect to. Of course, this process in highly error prone, but
=
most of these connection will be lost anyway. The general hypothesis is
tha=
t as we the circuitry uses some neural pathways, some synapses are
strength=
ened while others are disengaged. There is a large research
literature on s=
ynaptic plasticity dealing with just this issue. Be
advised, the molecular =
mechanisms underlying plasticity are relatively
well understood, but the po=
pular learning rule "what fires together,
wires together" is an over-simpli=
fication. Coming back to connectivity,
yes, there are axons as long as one =
meter, yes they connect distant
parts of the brain with very specific parts=
 of the spinal cord. There
are also across the brain distant connections, e=
ither in the same
hemisphere (called association pathways), across hemisphe=
res
(commissures, e.g. the corpus callosum) and from lower brain structures=

to the cortex (projection pathways, e.g. the thalamus to cortex). The
conn=
ections are very, very precise, down to specialized bunches of cells
(calle=
d nuclei). For example, neurons in the retina synapse directly to
the later=
al geniculate nucleus (LGN) which is just a bunch of cells in
the thalamus.=
 From there other neurons send axons to the very back of
the cortex in the =
occipital lobe to what is know as the primary visual
cortex (Broadman area =
17). This general brain organization, with this
level of precision, is cons=
istently the same across most human adult
brains with no impairments, with =
some well studied and subtle
differences, for example between males-females=
, etc. The consensus about
how this precise organization is possible is tha=
t genetic factors build
this organ in the same way they build a heart, i.e.=
 very precisely down
to cellular level, cell-architecture and placement, ce=
ll connectivity.
Then, years of interaction with the environment fine tune =
the neural
circuits by what we call implicit and explicit learning, but to =
put it
simply, the fine-tuning is done just by "using" the brain, i.e. seei=
ng
is fine-tuned by seeing, hearing by hearing and so on.... We are talking=

about an "ecosystem" of 100 billion living cells working together in DNA
s=
pecified ways, that incidentally exhibits a self, language, imagination
and=
 the rest of what we call human. This "construction" stemming from
the DNA =
blueprint is exact enough to generate many healthy human
children who end u=
p with almost identically wired brains, while being
plastic enough to deal =
with all the learning, adaptation and even
miss-wiring that happens.

Also =
last year I came across this article that discusses work
regarding expressi=
on of bits of DNA considered to be junk acquired
from ancient viruses and t=
he like:

"A special report on the human genome: The soul of an old machine=
"
http://www.economist.com/node/16349410
<http://www.economist.com/node/163=
49410>


I've appened some of the salient parts to the end of this post. Th=
is
junk DNA appears to be expressed more in brain tissue than elsewhere
in =
the body, and so there's a question of why this is and if it has
any purpos=
e. One suggested purpose is that this DNA is used as a
source of complexity=
 in brain connectivity growth processes in the
embryo. It's possible that t=
he learning processes/rules in the brain
don't require any specific structu=
re but do requrie some existing
structure with sufficient interconnectivity=
 and 'messiness' to build
upon, and that these large sequences of 'junk' DN=
A (I appreciate junk
DNA is a loaded term) were a convenient source of mess=
iness or
arbitrary complexity that evolution came to utilise over time.

Do=
 you think this is possible? Likely? or just another madcap theory? :)

If =
you want to what is considered fact and what is informed speculation
(and w=
hat the evidence behind that speculation is) I wholeheartedly
recommend rea=
ding an introductory neuroscience textbook, your choice.
They are surprisin=
gly accessible and at the end of 300 pages you will
know what facts and the=
ories are supported by converging evidence and
where a consensus was reache=
d or is growing. The web  is full of 
speculations which generally show jus=
t one opinion.


I personally find conclusions of the article highly specul=
ative and
inexact, although they are in line with the general current
under=
standing. I take it a pure confabulation simply because they do not
explain=
 the characteristics of their proposed evolutionary model. There
are clearl=
y components of intelligence, and pretty much any aspect of
brain activity,=
 which are not completely described genetically. The
genetics are just a gu=
ideline; experience literally shapes the brain.
Its physiology is built to =
feature this level of plasticity. The
mechanisms behind this plasticity, th=
e neural code and how the pieces of
information we know come together to fe=
ature "intelligence" are really
just beginning to be understood. This is la=
rgely why such speculations
still make the headlines.

Best regards,
Andrei=
